Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Parental influence on risky behavior and decision-making in adolescent girls

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Adolescence is a time in which many engage in risky decision-making, as evidenced by increased rates of car accidents, crime, binge drinking and other negative health behaviors. It is therefore critical to understand the life experiences and pathways that influence these risky behaviors in adolescents. The social context (e.g., parents, peers) may be a critical component for understanding adolescent decision-making and risk-taking behaviors. For example, several previous studies have shown that paternal absence or disengagement can be risk factors for risky behaviors and decision-making in daughters. Although research has established this phenomenon, the causal nature of this relationship has not been determined. Additionally, it is unclear what proximal psychological changes occur in response to paternal absence or disengagement that promote these negative outcomes. Dr. Bruce Ellis (University of Arizona), Dr. Sarah Hill (Texas Christian University), and their colleagues will combine a powerful natural experiment with five rigorous laboratory experiments to examine the role of paternal engagement in regulating daughters' attitudes and decision-making.

Through integration of theory and methods from evolutionary, developmental, and social psychology, the proposed research will test for causation and mechanism. Such knowledge is potentially transformative because it could help move the field toward a more comprehensive understanding of the developmental contexts and intervening mechanisms through which risky behaviors and decision-making occur. This interdisciplinary approach will foster synergistic, integrative connections between different research domains. Additionally, the proposed research will involve training for undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The current research examines the role of fathers in regulating daughters’ sexual attitudes, decision-making, and risky sexual behavior. The main focus of this project was on extending a rigorous program of research into the effects of fathers on daughters’ sexual development and risk taking. To address the limitations inherent in past research, this project utilized a powerful natural experiment in addition to complementary randomized experiments to test for the impact of father absence and disengagement on young women’s sexual psychology and risky sexual behavior—to determine whether and how fathers influence daughters’ sociosexual outcomes. We collected data from adult biological sister pairs which allowed us to examine the effects of differential exposure of sisters within families to father absence and investment while growing up, independent of genetic and environmental factors that vary between families. We found evidence that older sisters (who experienced greater exposure to their fathers while growing up) were more strongly influenced by the quality of fathering they received in terms of calibrating their expectations for male relationship investment in adulthood and their own risky sexual behavior. Specifically, older sisters who experienced lower quality fathering during childhood reported lower expectations for investment in their relationships with men and engaged in more risky sexual behavior relative to older sisters who received higher quality fathering during childhood. This relationship between fathering quality and male relationship investment expectations and risky sexual behavior was absent for younger sisters (who spent relatively less time living with their fathers compared to their older sisters). The effects of fathering quality on risky sexual behavior were mediated by lower levels of parental monitoring and greater affiliation with peers who engaged in risky sexual behaviors.

 

By providing a critical test of predictions derived from paternal investment theory, the results of this research suggest that: (a) a causal relationship exists between low quality fathering and daughters’ psychosexual development and, in turn, (b) intervention strategies aimed at promoting daughters’ healthy physical and psychological development by way of improving their interactions with their fathers are likely to be effective. Such knowledge is potentially transformative because it can help move the field beyond current debates regarding the problem of genetic and environmental confounds in fatherhood research and toward a more comprehensive understanding of the developmental contexts and intervening mechanisms through which women’s risky sexual decision-making and behavior are likely to occur.
